demos.title: PetsCanDate - A dating site for pets
demos.description: A dating site for pets built with Nuxt.js and Netlify as part of Netlifys 'Dusty Domains' campaign.

demos.title: Ecommerce site with Shopify Storefront APIs and SvelteKit
demos.description: The Shopify team recently announced enhancements to their Storefront APIs that make it possible for store owners to access and manage their entire store and inventory via APIs. This demo uses those APIs to build an e-commerce template with SvelteKit.

demos.title: Jamstack site with Docs, Blog and Shop sections built wt Nuxt.js and Netlify
demos.description: This demo uses Nuxt.js and Netlify to show a typical Jamstack site. I built it in an attempt to explain how developers can split large sites into independent microsites.

demos.title: Random user generator with Next.js useSWR
demos.description: Learn the basics of the useSWR hook with this random user generator demo built with Next.js.

demos.title: Local news site with Next.js and On-demand builders
demos.description: Looking for a way to explain the benefits of On-demand builders to folks? here's one. This demo is built with Next.js and uses ODB to generate the headline news at build time, and the rest on-demand.

demos.title: Local news site with Gatsby 4 SSG rendering on Netlify
demos.description: Looking for a way to explain the benefits of On-demand builders to folks? here's one. This demo is built with Gatsby and uses ODB to generate the headline news at build time, and the rest on-demand.

demos.title: Mealzers - food ordering site bulit with Gridsome, Strapi, and Snipcart
demos.description: This is an Ecommerce site built as a 6 part series on Strapi. It uses Strapi as a headless CMS, Gridsome at the static site generator and Snipcart to manage cart functionalities.

demos.title: On-Demand Meals restuarant site with Gridsome, GraphQL and ODB
demos.description: This demo examplifies how to use On-demand builders to fetch deferred content at request time using Gridsome.

demos.title: Ecommerce site with Sanity and Nuxt
demos.description: This demo was built while making the Jamstack Explorers mission titled 'Building with Sanity and Nuxt.'

demos.title: Event registration site with the Vue Composition API and Serverless functions
demos.description: A simple HTML form built to demonstrate how the Vue composition API pairs up nicely with serverless functions.

contents.title: Leveraging community for product growth
contents.description: When you build a community the right way, the immediate results are organic customer acquisition and retention & quality feedback.

contents.title: How to Jamstack in a dynamic era
contents.description: There’s a general misconception that since Jamstack sites and applications don't rely on traditional server architectures, they come at the cost of dynamic, powerful experiences. The reality is, Jamstack sites are great for creating highly dynamic, interactions using powerful tools like serverless functions and a variety of third-party services. In this session, we'll look at how a Jamstack architecture, with serverless functions and Strapi CMS, help developers deliver scale, performance, and a rich content authoring experience, without the burden of servers or infrastructure to maintain

contents.title: Speeding up build times in the Jamstack with DPR in Next.js
contents.description: The Jamstack way of building the web is highly optimized for speed and performance. This is owing to the fact that all the assets required in your site will be pre-generated at build time and made available to your users. But what happens when your site grows and you have to pre-generate thousands of pages and assets, your build times will increase. Long build times will consequently impact productivity and increase hosting costs. In this session, we looked at a few ways to conveniently scale Jamstack applications without losing the core benefits of the Jamstack like speed, efficiency, rollbacks and more.

contents.title: Bridging Design and Development in Style
contents.description: We follow a very traditional path when developing web applications and websites. We sketch out the ideas, and product designers create designs in Figma, while engineers build them to pixel perfection. This approach takes a lot of work from everyone, as designers must create the designs, prototype, and hand off all the resources and assets. From there, engineers must build the project, integrate it with the right frameworks, test it, and ship it to production.

contents.title: Writing Documentations That Don’t Suck!
contents.description: Documentation is a critical part of software development, yet it is often overlooked or undervalued.

contents.title: Reactivity in Vue3
contents.description: Have you ever wondered “Should I use ref or reactive?” When working with Vue 3’s Composition API? During the #JSWORLDAfrica conference, @kenny_io walks us through the technical differences between themStar-struck

contents.title: Token-Based Access Control On The Web
contents.description: Token-gated websites are a revolutionary way to conditionally grant access to online content using the power of blockchain technology.

contents.title: Unlocking Dev Super powers with SvelteKit
contents.description: SvelteKit gives developers the ability to do more with less. Less code, less energy, and consequently less time. More so, it gives you all the SEO benefits of single-page applications with client-side routing for almost instant navigation. Talk about the best of both worlds. With the techniques we'll discuss in this talk, you'll learn how to get the best of SvelteKit and unlock the superpowers you never knew you had

contents.title: Track Everything, measure everything, it will not be enough
contents.description: Measuring the impact of our activities and communicating how it adds value to the company is the general challenge of every DevRel team.

contents.title: Bridge'ing the Nuxt Gap
contents.description: Nuxt 3 is out in public beta with new features like the new nuxi CLI command, SSR and SSG, Script setup, Nitro engine and so on. We are all excited about these improvements, but what does it mean for the rest of our Nuxt 2 applications? Are we left out of the fun and improvements? Well, no. In this session, I’ll show you how to progressively enhance a Nuxt 2 application to use Nuxt 3 features using the Nuxt Bridge module.

contents.title: Advanced Rendering patterns in the Jamstack
contents.description: The Jamstack way of building the web is highly optimized for speed and performance. This is owing to the fact that all the assets required in your site will be pre-generated at build time and made available to your users. However, this introduces a huge overhead for developers and enterprises building large sites as the build times can quickly get out of hand. Lately, we've seen new patterns and techniques emerge from the community that solves this overhead in very practical ways. In this session, I'll go over these patterns (Sharding, ISR, DPR, DSG) and show our viewers and 2million+ other Jamstack developers how to leverage them to build large sites without the overhead on lengthy build times.

contents.title: Uses
contents.description: I get asked often about my work set up and I've seen other people share their tools and gears this way so here's mine:

children.value: I get asked often about my work set up and I've seen other people share their tools and gears this way so here's mine:
MacBook Pro (16-inch, 2021) 1TB SSD Storage¹ Apple M1 Max
LG-27UL850-W 27 inch IPS LED UHD Monitor With 60Hz, AMD FreeSync and DisplayPort HDMI VGA Black/Silver (x2)
Gator Frameworks Deluxe Desk-Mounted Broadcast Microphone Boom Stand
RGB Gaming Mouse Pad, Extra Large Soft Led Extended Mouse pad, anti-slip Rubber Base Computer Keyboard Mat
Visual Studio Code is my code editor of choice. Paired with the wonderful night-owl theme by Sarah Drasner, I couldn't ask for more.

I have both iTerm2 and hyper and honestly, I love them both. Which one I use really depends on which comes to mind first when I need a terminal. That said, I've been using Fig mostly in the last couple of weeks, I just like the auto completioning capabilities.
is my password manager of choice. I go introduced to password managers this year, I started off with 1Password and I don't think I'll ever go back to managing my passwords on my own again.

: Google Calendar and Clockwise pairs up really nicely to give me all the things I need. I've heard of fancier calendar tools that I should probably check out some time but I'll stick with those until then.
